November 13, 2005: Fiction
PREDATOR, by Patricia Cornwell. (Putnam, $26.95.) On the trail of a possible
serial killer, Dr. Kay Scarpetta turns to a jailed psychopath for advice.
AT FIRST SIGHT, by Nicholas Sparks. (Warner, $24.95.) The young couple from
"True Believer," who are now expecting a child, receive a disturbing message.
THE CAMEL CLUB, by David Baldacci. (Warner, $26.95.) A group of eccentric
conspiracy theorists stumbles across an actual plot reaching to the highest levels
of government.
TOXIC BACHELORS, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $27.) On a Mediterranean
vacation, three resolutely single friends meet three impressive women.
KNIFE OF DREAMS, by Robert Jordan. (Tor/Tom Doherty, $29.95.) Book 11 of
the Wheel of Time fantasy series.
THE LINCOLN LAWYER, by Michael Connelly. (Little, Brown, $26.95.) A Los
Angeles criminal defense attorney takes a case that proves more complicated and
dangerous than he expected.
CONSENT TO KILL, by Vince Flynn. (Atria, $25.95.) A spy is the target of an
international conspiracy spawned by the father of a terrorist he killed.
SAVING FISH FROM DROWNING, by Amy Tan. (Putnam, $26.95.) The
misadventures and misunderstandings of 12 American tourists in China and
Burma.
SON OF A WITCH, by Gregory Maguire. (ReganBooks/HarperCollins, $26.95.) Liir
makes his way through the dangerous land of Oz; a sequel to "Wicked."
A WEDDING IN DECEMBER, by Anita Shreve. (Little, Brown, $25.95.) Seven
former schoolmates reunite for a wedding and remember the tragedy that drove
them apart.
GABRIEL'S ANGEL, by Nora Roberts. (Silhouette, $17.95.) On a snowy night in
Colorado, a man saves a stranded pregnant woman and joins her custody battle
after falling in love.
BLUE SMOKE, by Nora Roberts. (Putnam, $25.95.) An arson investigator whose
family suffered a fire when she was a child is menaced by a sociopath.
THE AMBLER WARNING, by Robert Ludlum. (St. Martin's, $25.95.) A former
clandestine operative escapes from a government psychiatric prison and tries to
re-establish his identity.
A BREATH OF SNOW AND ASHES, by Diana Gabaldon. (Delacorte, $28.) In
1772, the British governor of North Carolina asks Jamie to support the king, but
Jamie's time-traveling wife assures him independence is inevitable; an Outlander
November 13, 2005
Non-Fiction
THE TRUTH (WITH JOKES), by Al Franken. (Dutton, $25.95.) A comic attack on
the Bush administration from the author of "Lies (and the Lying Liars Who Tell
Them)."
THE YEAR OF MAGICAL THINKING, by Joan Didion. (Knopf, $23.95.) The
author's attempts to come to terms with the death of her husband and the grave
illness of their only daughter.
TEAM OF RIVALS, by Doris Kearns Goodwin. (Simon & Schuster, $35.) The
political genius of Abraham Lincoln, revealed in his relationship with his cabinet,
from the author of "No Ordinary Time."
THE WORLD IS FLAT, by Thomas L. Friedman. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $27.50.)
A columnist for The New York Times analyzes 21st-century economics and
foreign policy and presents an overview of globalization trends.
DRIVEN FROM WITHIN, by Michael Jordan, edited by Mark Vancil. (Atria, $35.)
The basketball legend and businessman reflects on his career and the values that
helped him succeed, in stories, drawings and photographs.
THE CITY OF FALLING ANGELS, by John Berendt. (Penguin, $25.95.) The
author of "Midnight in the Garden of Good and Evil" investigates a fire in Venice.
FREAKONOMICS, by Steven D. Levitt and Stephen J. Dubner. (Morrow, $25.95.)
A maverick scholar applies economic thinking to everything from sumo wrestlers
who cheat to legalized abortion and the falling crime rate.
DEAN AND ME (A LOVE STORY), by Jerry Lewis and James Kaplan.
(Doubleday, $26.95.) The funnier half of Martin and Lewis remembers his time
with the man he calls "my partner."
MY FBI, by Louis J. Freeh with Howard Means. (St. Martin's, $25.95.) The director
of the F.B.I. from 1993 to 2001 describes his career.
1776, by David McCullough. (Simon & Schuster, $32.) An account of America's
founding year by the Pulitzer Prize-winning author, focusing on the inexperienced
George Washington and heroic citizen soldiers.
BLINK, by Malcolm Gladwell. (Little, Brown, $25.95.) The author of "The Tipping
Point" explores the importance of hunch and instinct to the workings of the mind.
MY FRIEND LEONARD, by James Frey. (Riverhead, $24.95.) The author of the
addiction memoir "A Million Little Pieces" remembers a helpful mobster friend.
A MAN WITHOUT A COUNTRY, by Kurt Vonnegut. (Seven Stories, $23.95.)
Autobiographical essays and observations from the author of "Slaughterhouse-
Five."
